comments.commentBody: It is a little early to re-crown apple king, with just a watch. I still would rather where my Rolex, or any other watch, than try and read the tiniest screen available for a smartphone/watch.

I'm sorry, but if you don't know how to change the time on your clock radio or get Windows to work (I use Windows everyday), then you've got more serious problems.  Anybody can learn how to do those things.  You don't need to give up and fork over hundreds of dollars or a thousand dollars to make things usable for yourself.

My first-generation iPad is working fine on the site. But I understand the new operating system about to come out won't work on these oldest iPads. I'm used to Apple's frequent operating system upgrades that periodically are not backwards compatible on older devices. But I'd hoped for more on this.

As usual every time Apple releases a new smartphone everybody gushes over it in all reality they're playing catch up to their competitors. what was released today is 3 year old technology and most smart phone users now know it. To some Apple is nothing but a status symbol to those of us that are serious about getting the best smartphone Apple is not the way to go. In the latest smart phone review in Consumer Reports who is completely unbiased ranked the previous iPhone 5s eighth so what does that tell you...!!!!
Doesn't AAPL virtually always dip after new product announcements?

I was underwhelmed at first because I couldn't think of a reason to buy the Watch.

Apple Pay, the killer app for the phone/watch combo, will never be implemented in Australia or anywhere outside the US.

Then I read a comment further down about heart attacks & realised how brilliant this device will be as a medical alert.

Much nicer & more comfie than the things you wear around your neck. Given the numbers, I can see the kids buying the phone & watch as an elegant way of keeping an eye on the parents.

Apple puts out good products. I've bought some laptops that haven't held up, yet my macbook circa 2000, operating on ox9.4, is still working like new (when plugged into an outlet). Only 1 of my multiple laptops had a logic board issue. None of my iphones ever malfunctioned, although battery life for each eventually becomes an issue. I still have the 2nd version of the ipod, which also works, I only wish I could find a replacement battery.

That's the good.

Here's the bad: Lack of support for previous operating systems from one of the richest companies on earth. Abandonment of the creative community that saw Apple's hardware, software and OS and as being intuitive and solid. Sure, the products they produce continue to be top of the line regarding it's hardware and integration with it's multiple devices, but icloud is exorbitantly priced for anything above 25gbd.

Do they still make pc's?

I'll get the 6, I don't care about the watch now, I'm not keen on the screen size, but I'll probably wonder how I ever lived with the 4" once I have it
They don't do that.
Well said, sir!
So Apple announced slightly larger phones, NFC mobile payments and a smartwatch and suddenly playing catch up is innovative or ground breaking?
Out of curiosity, did you wear a watch before?
And what pocket would you be carrying a 6" phone in? It's a phone, not an iPad.
Who said anything about a pocket?     The 6-incher would be a PHABLET and not a phone.   There are plenty of small tablets that size out there.

The headline for this article doesn't quite match the content, especially the end.  I agree, the phone size choices are a bit odd.  I'd say the 4.7-inch model is a bit too small, and the 5.5-inch is a bit too small for a phablet, especially given the size of the iPad Mini.   Something around 6 to 6.5 inches would have made more sense I think.
I would get the Apple Watch if it were not linked to the iPhone. I prefer Android and HTC, but that Watch looks hot.

I want a new apple computer platform that is fast, efficient and gives me choices of models for different applications. I need computing devices to help me create content and art.  I don't need expensive point of purchase devices that only consume second hand media already regurgitated by a myriad of social media apps. I remember when Apple thought different and made the tools for others to do the same, sadly those days are seemingly over.
No cell phone? The invention that is lifting entire societies out of the dark ages just doesn't do it for you, eh?

I agree.  I've never understood this prestige factor.  Sure, Android phones get discounted soon enough (largely because the product cycle is much faster); but whether the phone is $1, $50, $100, or $200 (and rarely more because most come with card slots so you don't get gouged for memory), the bulk of the cost is the contract or buying data and voice month-by-month.
I don't know, Samsung TVs are not that complicated to figure out.   But like Android, they give you many more options than a lot of other TVs.

Sam -- not true.  "Smartwatches" have been out for 2 or 3 yrs now, and I have yet to see my first one on a grown-up although I am traveling extensively between the trendier parts of large cities on the East Coast. You can't sustain the Apple stock price on a bunch of Valley hipsters.

We should save the effusive praise until we see how revolutionary the watch actually becomes. Short demo videos do little to demonstrate its game changing potential. I remember thinking I would never use an iPad and now commonly use it. It's hard to see how the watch will "redefine" watches right now but a little time will demonstrate whether it is a success or flop.

Ha ha, this reads like one of your old Slate pieces.  Did you forget to put your oxygen mask on when it dropped from above?  I have all things Apple and this was a pretty dull set of announcements.  A Samsung-esque iPhone that I don't really need and a smartwatch that looks pretty drab and unnecessary.  But by all means cry hysterical tears Farhad.  And when you check the time on your Apple Watch - oh whoops battery ran out and you now have to charge yet another thing that didn't used to need it.

I got the album, and listened to it using my over-priced macbook pro that I won't be replacing now that I've switched to a Samsung Galaxy S5. Best phone I've ever owned.

When this laptop dies, I'm finished with Apple products.

Not going to pay the extra cash for their laptops etc anymore. Not worth the extra money. Too little computing power for the money vs the competition.

How do we know they're great products when nobody has used them yet?

I don't think anybody under the age of 50 is going to be "miffed" because we're not getting a free U2 album... As if anyone under 30 pays for albums anyways...

Today's event showed that Apple can still innovate and produce great products post-Jobs. And they still know how to introduce those products with a bang. My guess is the naysayers are miffed because they aren't among the half-billion people who got the U2 album for free. And then there is the usual gaggle of Apple enviers. In any case, naysayers should probably keep to the sidelines for their own safety, lest they be trampled by the hordes who enjoy using Apple products and who will be buying iPhone 6 and Apple Watch.
Lucky you.
I'd rather the paramedics just use the defibrillators and get me to a hospital instead of scrolling through an Apple Watch.
Apple's decent into mediocrity is confirmed. Others lead the market.

Yes, because Wall Street was 2 years ago talking how Apple was doomed and the stock was worth $250 billion (today it is worth $589 billion).   Wall Street is land of those who know the price of everything and the value of nothing.

I like my gizmos as much as anyone. But, if you need a device on your wrist to help improve your health, you're not going to get very healthy anytime soon. All you need to know is how to walk, or run. You don't need to know how many times your heart beats per minute, only that it's going fast.
What's next? An app to tell you that you're in love, based on your heartbeat? Because you couldn't tell without it?
